snippet: German legislation may offer a chance for permanent residency to young asylum seekers like Reem Sahwil, who had a tearful exchange with Angela Merkel.
abstract: Reem Sahwil, 14-year-old Palestinian girl who has lived and attended school in Germany for five years, becomes powerful symbol of European migrant crisis when video of her crying during exchange with Chancellor Angela Merkel circulates on Internet; encounter was filmed at public youth forum where Merkel candidly stated that not all asylum seekers would be allowed to stay in Germany; some have criticized remarks for lack of empathy while others have praised them as honest.

byline.contributor: Victor Homola contributed reporting from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: German legislation may offer a chance for permanent residency to young asylum seekers like Reem Sahwil, who had a tearful exchange with Angela Merkel.

headline.main: Tearful Moment With Merkel Turns Migrant Girl Into a Potent Symbol
